columns.text: In this problem, we will determine the present value of the savings if a company saves $47,000 each year from its revenue for seven years, and the appropriate interest rate is 7.1%

Let's start by discussing what the present value is.

The present value refers to the current value of a future cash flow. The number of periods, interest rates, and cash amount is used to calculate the present value future or series of cash flows.

We'll use a spreadsheet function called PV, or the present value computation formula, to calculate the present value of the savings. As a result, we'll use the PV syntax on the spreadsheet:

$$\begin{aligned}
PV&=(\text{rate},nper,pmt,[fv],[type]) \\
\end{aligned}$$


Where:

$PV$, which means the present value
$nper$, which refers to the period\
$pmt$, which represents the cash payment\
$fv$, the future value\
$type$, which indicates the basis of the calculation, either year-end or beginning of the year

The savings each year of $47,000 will be the cash amount on our procedure, the rate is the interest rate of 7.1% and the period is seven years. Hence, we'll consider the following details in our calculation:

| Particulars  |         |
|--------------|---------|
| Cash payment | $47,000 |
| Rate         | 7.1%    |
| Period       | 7 years |

Let's now calculate the present value of the savings in the spreadsheet. The cash amount should be negative for the function to work correctly.

!['slader'](https://slader-solution-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com/94bedbc1-d1a9-4c35-b291-02583b84247c-1652195874497195.png)


**Hence, the value of the savings of the company is $252,415.91**
In this exercise, we will determine the present value of the company's savings.

**Annuity** represents a series of equal payments (receipts or disbursements), done regularly (yearly, monthly) in a particular time period. **The present value of an annuity** represents the cash value of all future annuity payments when a particular discount rate is given.

In our exercise, the company generates a series of equal annual revenues (savings) for several years and gets an interest rate. These savings represent annuity since they are equal and done regularly during the period of  7 years. Thus, we could use the annuity present value formula in order to determine the present value of future savings:
$$\text{PV of an Annuity}=\text{C}\times\dfrac{1-\left[\dfrac{1}{\left(1+\text{r}\right)^\text{t}}\right]}{\text{r}}$$

Where:

C = Annuity (Cash Flow Amount)\
r = Interest Rate\
t = Number of Periods

Let's first identify the given amounts in a problem:

|Variables| Values| 
|--|--| 
|Annuity |$47,000 | 
|Interest Rate |$\hspace{5pt}$ 7.1% | 
|Number of Periods|$\hspace{9pt}$ 7|
